text.eng: XVIII.— EXPEDITION OF CLEOMENES AGAINST ARGOS.

text.lat: 209.— Cleomeni, Spartano regi Delphicum oraculum consulenti, redditum erat responsum, ‘capturum illum Argos.’ Itaque in Argivorum fines cum exercitu profectus est. Postquam vero ad fluvium pervenit Erasinum, quem aiunt ex Stymphalio lacu effluere: (dicunt enim, hunc lacum, postquam in caecam voraginem se infuderit, rursus apparere in Argolide, et exinde hanc aquam vocari Erasinum ab Argivis); hostias flumini immolavit. Quum vero extis monstraretur, infelicem fore transitum, laudare se ait flumen, quod cives non proderet suos; sed ne sic quidem salvos evasuros Argivos.
text.eng: 209.— To Cleomenes, the Spartan king consulting the Delphic oracle, the response was given, 'he will capture Argos.' Therefore, he set out with his army into the territory of the Argives. When he reached the river Erasinus, which they say flows out from the Stymphalian lake (for they say this lake, after pouring into a blind chasm, reappears in Argolis, and thence this water is called Erasinus by the Argives), he sacrificed victims to the river. When it was shown by the entrails that the passage would be unlucky, he praised the river for not betraying its own citizens; but he still declared that the Argives would not escape safely.

text.lat: 210.— Post haec retrogressus, et tauro mari immolato, navibus duxit exercitum in Argivorum fines. Qua re cognita, ad mare properant Argivi, opem suis laturi. Tum castra castris Lacedaemoniorum, haud magno spatio in medio relicto, opposuerunt. Ibi pugnam ex aperto non verebantur, sed ne dolo caperentur; Pythia enim oraculum ediderat his verbis: Verum, quando marem praevertet femina victrix. Inter et Argivos referet praelustris honorem; Tunc Argivarum reddet plerasque gementes; Occidet et telis sinuoso corpore serpens.
text.eng: 210.— After these things, having gone back and sacrificed a bull to the sea, he led his army by ships into the territory of the Argives. When this thing was known, the Argives hurried to the sea to bring aid to their own. Then they placed their camp opposite the camp of the Lacedaemonians, leaving not much space in between. There, they were not afraid of an open fight, but of being caught by a trick; for the Pythia had issued an oracle with these words: 'But when a victorious woman surpasses a man, Between and among the Argives, she will bring back illustrious honor; Then she will render most of the Argive women groaning; And the serpent with a winding body will fall by weapons.'

text.lat: 211.— Proinde consilium ceperunt utendi hostium praecone: idque ita exsecuti sunt, ut, quoties Spartanus praeco signum aliquod dedisset, Argivi etiam id ipsum facerent. Quos ubi Cleomenes cognovit idem exsequi, quod ipsius praeco significasset; imperat suis, ut, quando prandii signum edidisset praeco, tunc arma caperent, et Argivos adorirentur. Quod fecerunt Lacedaemonii. Nam, dum Argivi ex praeconis imperio prandium capiebant, subito illos adorti, magnum numerum interfecerunt, alios multos, qui in Argi lucum confugerant, circumsedentes ibi custodiverunt.
text.eng: 211.— Therefore, they took the plan to use the enemy's herald: and they executed it in such a way that whenever the Spartan herald gave a signal, the Argives would do the same thing. When Cleomenes noticed that they were doing the same as his herald had signaled, he ordered his men to take up arms and attack the Argives when the herald gave the signal for dinner. The Lacedaemonians did this. For, while the Argives were having lunch according to the herald's order, having suddenly attacked them, they killed a great number, and many others, who had fled into the grove of Argus, they besieged and guarded there.

text.lat: 212.— Deinde hoc fecit Cleomenes. Quum e transfugis quibusdam cognosset, quinam essent ex Argivis qui in sacro luco inclusi essent, misso praecone nominatim vocavit singulos, affirmans, ‘se pretium redemptionis illorum accepturum.’ Statutum autem apud Peloponnesios est pretium redemptionis, binae minae pro singulis captivis pendendae. Itaque quinquaginta fere Argivorum vocatos interfecit Cleomenes; quod reliquis, qui in luco erant, ignotum erat: quum enim magnus esset lucus, qui intus erant, non videbant quid faceret. Postremo vero unus illorum conscensa arbore vidit quid gereretur; atque exinde non amplius egrediebantur vocati.
text.eng: 212.— Then Cleomenes did this. When he learned from certain deserters who among the Argives were enclosed in the sacred grove, he sent a herald and called them by name, affirming that he would accept a ransom for them. It is decreed among the Peloponnesians that the ransom price is two minas for each captive. Thus, Cleomenes killed nearly fifty of the Argives who had been called; what was unknown to the rest, who were in the grove, was that, since the grove was large, those inside could not see what was happening. Finally, one of them climbed a tree and saw what was being done; and from that point on, they no longer came out when called.

text.lat: 213.— Tum vero Cleomenes hilotas omnes iussit materiem circa lucum congerere: quo facto lucum incendit. Iamque dum ardebat lucus, ex transfuga quaesivit, ‘cui deo sacer lucus esset.’ Qui ubi respondit, ‘Argi lucum esse;’ hoc audito Cleomenes, ingentem edens gemitum, ait: ‘O fatidice Apollo, magnopere me decepisti, quum me Argos capturum diceres. Suspicor enim exisse mihi id vaticinium.’ Post haec, maiore exercitus parte Spartam dimissa, ipse cum mille fortissimis ad Iunonis templum se contulit, sacra facturus. Quum autem sacrificare vellet, vetuit sum sacerdos dicens, nefas esse peregrinum sacra ibi facere. At Cleomenes, iussis hilotis abductum ab ara sacerdotem verberare, ipse sacra fecit; quo facto Spartam rediit.
text.eng: 213.— Then Cleomenes commanded all the Helots to gather wood around the grove: having done so, he set fire to the grove. And while the grove was burning, he asked from a deserter to which god the grove was sacred. When he responded that it was sacred to Argive, Cleomenes, hearing this, let out a loud groan, saying: 'O prophetic Apollo, you have greatly deceived me, when you said I would capture Argos. I suspect that the prophecy was meant for me.' After this, having dismissed most of his army to Sparta, he went with a thousand of the bravest to the temple of Juno, to perform sacred rites. When he wanted to sacrifice, the priest forbade him, saying it was unlawful for a foreigner to perform sacred rites there. But Cleomenes, having ordered the priest to be taken away from the altar and beaten by the Helots, performed the rites himself; having done so, he returned to Sparta.

text.lat: 214.— Spartae vero inimici eum apud ephoros reum egerunt: aiebant enim, ‘pecunia corruptum Argos non cepisse, quum capere facillime potuisset.’ At ille respondit, ‘postquam lucum Argo sacrum cepisset, visum sibi exisse vaticinium dei: quare non tentandam urbem putavisse, priusquam sacris factis cognovisset, utrum traditurus sibi eam Deus esset, an impedimento futurus. Litanti autem sibi in Iunonis aede, ex simulacri pectore effulsisse flammam: itaque intellexisse se, Argos capi non posse: nam, si ex capite simulacri effulsisset flamma, capturum se urbem fuisse: quum vero e pectore effulsisset, effecta esse omnia quae Deus fieri voluisset.’ Itaque criminis absolutus est.
text.eng: 214.— In Sparta, his enemies brought a charge against him before the ephors: they said that he was bribed with money not to capture Argos, when he could have done it very easily. But he replied that after he captured the sacred grove of Argos, he thought the god's prophecy had come true; therefore, he thought the city should not be tried before he discovered, by performing the sacred rites, whether God had decided to surrender it to him or if he would be an obstacle. However, as he was performing rites in the temple of Juno, a flame flashed from the chest of the statue; thus he understood that Argos could not be taken: for if the flame had flashed from the head of the statue, he would have taken the city; but since it flashed from the chest, everything that the God wanted to be done was accomplished. Therefore, he was acquitted of the crime.

text.lat: 215.— Postea furor eum invasit: nam quoties Spartanus obviam ei veniret, huic sceptrum in faciem infligebat. Quae quum faceret, et alienata mente esset, vinxerunt eum propinqui, et ligno alligaverunt. At ille, ita vinctus, ubi vidit unum custodem, egressis ceteris, solum relictum, cultrum postulavit: quem quum ei statim dare nollet custos, minatus est homini quae deinde illi facturus esset; donec minis territus cultrum dedit. Tum vero, sumpto ferro, Cleomenes, initio a cruribus facto, misere se ipse laceravit. Postremo, ubi ad ventrem perventum est, hunc etiam dissecuit, donec animam efflavit.
text.eng: 215.— Afterwards madness seized him: for whenever a Spartan would meet him, he would strike him in the face with a scepter. When he did this and was of alienated mind, his family bound him and tied him to a wooden beam. But he, thus bound, when he saw one guard, the others having left, was left alone, asked for a knife: but when the guard did not immediately give it to him, he threatened the man with what he would then do to him; until, terrified by threats, the guard gave the knife. Then indeed, having taken the knife, Cleomenes, starting from his legs, miserably lacerated himself. Finally, when he came to his stomach, he even cut it open, until he breathed his last.

text.lat: 216.— Argivi aiebant ‘hoc eum fecisse, quoniam Argivos, qui e pugna in lucum Argi se recepissent, inde abductos trucidasset, ipsumque spreta relligione lucum incendisset.’ At Spartani arbitrantur, ‘non in furorem actum fuisse Cleomenem a deo quoquam, sed contraxisse morem bibendi merum, eaque de caussa in furorem incidisse.’ Haec apud Spartanos de Cleomene fama est.
text.eng: 216.— The Argives said 'he did this because the Argives, who had taken refuge in the grove of Argos from the battle, were dragged from there and slaughtered, and he had even burned the grove with religion having been despised.' However, the Spartans believe that Cleomenes hadn’t been driven to madness by any god, but he had contracted the habit of drinking neat wine, and from that cause had fallen into madness. This is the opinion among the Spartans about Cleomenes.
